docs.lead_paragraph: Women whose weight gain during pregnancy meets the current recommendations are significantly more likely to have a 3-year-old who is overweight than those who gain less than the recommended amount, researchers report. Guidelines from the Institute of Medicine say that a woman with a normal body-mass index of 19.8 to 26 should gain 25 to 35 pounds. Women with a lower than normal B.M.I. should gain slightly more, and those with a B.M.I. greater than 26 should gain 13 to 25 pounds.

headline.main: Findings Challenge Guidelines For Weight Gain in Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Researcher Dr Emily Oken leads study that suggests Institute of Medicine weight gain guidelines for pregnant women should be re-evaluated to help avoid childhood obesity; research, which is published in American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, finds women who gain less weight than suggested are less likely to have overweight toddlers; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM Timing and sexual position can influence a baby's sex. THE FACTS For couples who know they want a girl or a boy, there is always the fertility clinic. But is there a lower-tech method?
docs.abstract: Research does not support idea that timing of intercourse or sexual position can influence sex of baby; fifteen percent of women studied report having multiple orgasms; circumcision does not appear to decrease sexual satisfaction for men; drawings (M)
